subsection.title: Rational Function Definition
subsection.p: The functions listed below are rational functions.

li.p: \frac{1}{x}+\frac{x^{2}}{x-5}. In its current form this expression is the sum of two rational functions. Later we will see how we can combine the terms to write the expression as a ratio of polynomials.

subsection.p: Notice the definition states specifically that the ratio is made up of polynomials. That is important to remember. The functions listed below are NOT rational funcitons because either the numerator or the denominator is not a polynomial.

li.p: \frac{\sqrt{x}+1}{3x^{4}-x}. The square root in the numerator is the equivalent of x^{\frac{1}{2}} which is not a polynomial.
\frac{2x-x^{7}}{x^{4}-6^{x}}. In the denominator the term 6^{x} is exponential not a polynomial.

subsection.p: You may already be wondering if power functions have anything in common with polynomials and rational functions. The answer is yes, sometimes.
Some power functions are rational, some power functions are polynomials, and some power functions are neither rational nor polynomials.

li.p: \frac{1}{x^{2}} is a power function because it can be written as x^{-2}, but it is also a rational function because the numerator is 1, a polynomial of degree zero, and the denominator x^{2} is a polynomial of degree two.

Consider the power function x^{\frac{-1}{2}}. It is not a polynomial because the exponent is not a non-negative integer and it is not a rational function because it cannot be written as a ratio of polynomials.

exercise.title: Determine if each Function is Rational or Not

hint.p: In each case, ask yourself if each subterm is a polynomial.
Can the expression be written as a ration of polynomials?

li.p: Both the numerator and the denominator are polynomials. That is, each term in the numerator and the denominator is a polynomial.
In the numerator the term 5^{x} is exponential, so the entire expression is not a rational function.
In the numberator the term x^{x} is not a polynomial (the exponent is not a non-negative integer). Therefore, the entire expression is not a rational function.
Each term in the expression is a rational function. Therefore the sum of the terms is also a rational function.

subsection.title: Applications of Rational Functions
subsection.p: Rational functions sometimes occur when making comparisons between two quantities, hence the ratio.

introduction.p: Consider how the percent copper in a metal alloy changes as we add grams of copper to 50 grams of alloy. Intially the alloy has no copper in it.

statement.p: The percent copper in the alloy stems from the concentration (ratio of copper to the total metal) in the mix.
Divide the amount of copper by the total amount of metal (which includes the copper and the rest of the metal). This ratio can be converted into a percent by multiplying the result by 100 \%.

li.p: What is the percent copper in the metal alloy if no copper is added?
What is the percent copper in the metal alloy if 50 grams of copper are added?
If no copper is added, then zero grams out of 50 grams of the total alloy are copper. Therefore the ratio of copper to total alloy is \frac{}{+50}=0 which represents 0 \% copper.
If 50 grams of copper are added to the 50 grams of alloy then there is a total of 100 grams of alloy. So half of the total metal is copper. That's \frac{}{50+50}=0.5 which represents 50 \% copper.

exercise.title: A Formula for the Concentration of Copper in an Alloy

introduction.p: Find a formula to model the concentration of coppoer as a function of the amount of copper added to the alloy mixture.

li.p: Let x be the amount of copper, in grams, we add to the alloy. We want an expression that returns the concentration of copper as we add x grams of copper to an alloy that initially has no copper in it.
Remember, the idea is to write a rational function (fraction) that compares the amount of copper to the total amount of metal.
If x is the amount of copper we add, what should the numerator be? (HJint: what variable measures the amount of copper in the alloy?)

Initially there are only 50 grams of non-copper metal in the alloy. As we add copper, we are also adding to the total metal in the alloy. What should the denominator be? (Hint: the denominator includes copper and non-copper.)
Write one rational expression that models the concentration of copper in the alloy.
If x is the amount of copper we add to a mix with initially no copper in it, then the numerator is just x. If we add no copper then x=0.
The denominator is the total amount of metal in the alloy. Initially there are 50 grams of non-copper metal, but as we add x grams of copper then the denominator is 50+x.

In English we would say, There are x grams of copper out of 50+x grams of total metal in the alloy. An equivalent math expression is
\frac{x}{x+50}

subsection.p: Sometimes a function will not look rational but can be converted into a ratio of polynomials.

subsection.title: Long Run Behavior
subsection.p: Rational Functions have distinctive behaviors for inputs far from the origin versus inputs close to the origin. When consider the characteristics of a funciton when the inputs are far from the origin, we call it long-run behavior. long-run behavior
The graph initially shows two functions from a far away perspective. In math we call this the long-run behavior. long-run behavior

subsection.title: Short-run Behavior
subsection.p: Short-run behavior refers to any characteristics or special traits a function may have when the inputs are close to the origin.

In math close is any value that can be placed on a number line. In fact, if a value is NOT infinity, then it is considered close. As an application, three billion miles may seem far away, but it's nothing when compared to the size of the universe!
In the following execises you will explore the behavior of some rational functions for values near the origin.

subsection.title: Building a Rational Function
subsection.p: Using similar techniques for building a polynomial, we can use the zeros, vertical and horizontal asymptotes as guides to help us construct possible formulas for rational functions.
In the next exercise you will use specific properties of the graph of a rational function to construct a possible formula for a rational function.
